author: Grateful Grandson
title: Pain
body:
Yesterday I had a sudden onset of lower back pain and spasms.  
It was quite difficult because it was during the Christmas period and I had to spend 3 hours on the phone on two occasions, which was understandable.  
I wasn't overly impressed with the manner of member of staff, who gave no apology and fully justified no apology as they were covering the whole of Scotland in one call centre.  
However I did receive a phone call from a Doctor. Their manner was incredibly nice, as was the first person I spoke to at NHS24.  
I ended up trying anything yesterday after being in so much pain, I couldn't sit down or stand up, play with my kids or clean and tidy....  
Today is almost unbearable again... However I've just discovered that the Doctor has already arranged a prescription for me at the local pharmacy.  
Can I please say a huge thank you, the Doctor, and the a and e staff, as well as NHS24 at NHS borders, as today, and hopefully tomorrow, is going to be manageable. Thanks to your quick response.

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland

author: Emmrd63
title: Supportive advocacy service
body:
Theresa was really helpful. I feel so grateful having her there to support me with the doctor, who I felt did not want to listen to me.  
Theresa is an angel and I am so thankful to her and the organisation for the work you do and the support you give.

author: Chelle 1971
title: Ward 8 good hope
body: My mom has been in hospital for about 6 weeks she went in with cellulitis the beginning of November was in for four weeks with various infections she kept getting while in there she came home in the 15th December was back in on the 16th December as she still had an infection in thr past two weeks she has had a chest infection then hospital based pneumonia and now ecoli just to make the matters worse ward 8 at good hope have not answered the phone to me for the last three days 5 days ago I made 68 call to finally get through at 10pm at night the next day again I couldn't get through but got a call from a doctor who was very nice since then I have had no contact no one is answering the phone and even the main reception are frustrated with it I have contacted pals with no response and I am very worried for my mother I'm her only child and next of kin it's Christmas she probably thinks I have forgotten her

readBy.name: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust

author: J239
title: Unsung heroes
body:
I am aware how stretched the NHS are at present this is why I had to share the excellent care that my mother received while waiting for me to pick her up at the discharge lounge at Glasgow Royal Infirmary. Diane the staff nurse who cared for my mother makes me proud of the NHS.  
When I came to collect my mother who sadly has dementia from the discharge lounge she was sitting beside Diane while she was working singing her favourite songs from Frank Sinatra which Diane had learned was her favourite and found for her to help settle her. My mother loves singing.  
The nurse help her get changed into her clothes fixed her hair and explained in 5 minutes more about my mother's time in hospital and her medications than she had in her whole time in hospital. My mother spoke about this lovely girl all the way home and what a lovely time she had. Thank you so much for the care my mother had.

author: Adjb06
title: Painless first covid vaccination
body: Paul went over all the information before giving the jag. He was very friendly and reassuring. In and out again within 10 minutes and it didn’t even hurt.

author: aquariusfy79
title: Physiotherapy at Belfast City Hospital
body: I was very happy with the physio service received on Friday. This was very useful as i had requested it before from various people but had not received any help

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: BR07
title: Good experience following hospital admission
body:
I attended the Emergency Department as I had chest pain and was short of breath. I was found to have a collapsed lung. I was in shock but the ED team made me feel at ease. Dr Mackay was exceptional. He explained my treatment plan so I fully understood and showed me my x-ray.  
Due to the hospital being under pressure I had to stay in ED overnight, the staff were good. The porters I dealt with were also good, very friendly. I was then admitted to MAU for a night where also the staff were welcoming and nice. Overall I had a good experience during this challenging time the hospital faces.

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland

author: MrsP-V
title: Excellent Virtual visiting service
body:
Tonight we had a virtual visit with my Mum on Ward 1 at Lurgan Hospital who suffered a stroke in early December  
Thank you so much it was very much appreciated as we can’t visit during these restrictions on weekly visiting  
We could engage with Mum and with the patience of Sarah we had 30 precious minutes chatting to Mum .  
Thank you also to Tara in Virtual Visiting Team

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Nixs
title: Gold standard care
body:
I had a minor operation today at the Day procedure unit, Lagan Valley. The care felt gold standard throughout. From the initial meeting and talking me through the process the support and care was perfect for me throughout.  
The nursing and care staff of the DPU and theatre, and the medical staff all taking time to explain and reassure me. It felt like a partnership experience where I felt listened to and supported. Thanks to the wonderful team and great care.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: piscesyb79
title: I left feeling satisfied instead of being judged and worried
body:
I had my implant fitted today and I couldn't have been happier with the service. I've had it done once before at the Doctors and it wasn't the greatest experience but the nurses I had today were so lovely. They ran through everything with me twice to ensure I knew exactly what would happen and I was prepared and willing before I signed anything, and then they got me prepped and ready. I don't deal well with needles so they helped ease my nerves and took my mind off it and didn't go any further until I was 100% settled and ready to continue, checking that I couldn't feel the part of my arm that I had the implant put into, and then put the implant in. It was a bit uncomfortable and I bled quite a lot but both nurses kept me distracted and patched me up very quickly, running through the aftercare after I was up and walking around which took a few minutes to settle my head.  
They then made sure I was okay and offered condoms as they explained I'd still need to use them until I've had the implant in for a week before I left. I could not recommend this service enough, I would definitely rather go here than my doctors again, I'm so happy with how I was treated and how I left feeling satisfied instead of being judged and worried.

author: staffpatient22
title: Excellent care from the other side
body:
I'm a staff nurse in the NHS and attended A&E at the GRI this morning. I was seen quickly, treated well and can't thank the staff enough. To be clear, I was not seen quickly because I work in the NHS.  
The nurses, junior doctor and urology registrar were brilliant. They communicated well, checked in with me and chased the assessments I needed. I was discharged with a clear plan and very reassured about my presenting problem. I hope the staff appreciate how valuable and appreciated they are and I give my thanks to the ward management for their execellent team.

author: Slyfox
title: Staff lovely but better signage and care parking would help
body:
The nurse tried to explain it but finding the building wasn't easy. The building could do with its name written on the road side as you come off the main road going past the tile place for easier identification. I spent a while driving around looking for it, simply labeling better would greatly help. A couple of allocated parking spaces would be helpful too.
Waited longer than expected as was punctual to appointment as I know that's important now no not be hanging around.

Seen by 2 nurses. Both lovely people and friendly. Both made me feel at ease and ensured I was comfortable throughout my procedure and tests. I was offered more tests than I went in for and was greatful for the support. Was very happy with the level of care I was given. 

Was told to expect around a 45min appointment, was there for 1hr 15min. I didn't mind but babysitter was irritated.

author: Joaglolo
title: My time at a&e
body: I cannot put into words how amazing the staff are especially Albert who went above and beyond on nightduty and day duty New Year’s Eve, and also a nurse who worked night duty, 35 weeks pregnant and I cannot believe I forgot her name! She was an absolute angel! Rushed off her feet and she still managed to provide the best care to myself and two other patients awaiting beds. She also covered triage this specific night. She provided blankets, snacks, extra pillows, fresh water, This lady is a credit to the nursing profession! As is Albert!

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: Bell15
title: Incredible care in Fetal Medicine
body:
Fetal medicine is a part of the hospital I had never before given much thought about, and certainly not a place I ever thought I would end up in. But that’s exactly where we have been for the last few weeks. We were incredibly lucky and fortunate that all our investigations resulted in a good outcome but I just wanted to express my heartfelt thank you to Dr Ledingham and midwives Rhonda and Megan.  
Every consultation we had with them, whether in person for a chat, on the phone or in person for an invasive test was beyond anything we could have ever hoped for. They were incredibly professional and efficient but they all went about their work with such empathy and kindness. We were always made to feel like they had all the time in the world to sit and answer our many questions, when in reality it is a very busy department. No question was ever a stupid question and every answer was expertly and confidently answered in a way we would understand, whilst never shying from the truth or possible difficult outcomes. There are simply not enough words to describe the incredible care we received.  
I too, work for NHS GGC as a nurse specialist, and I just hope that my patients leave my clinic feeling half as well cared for and confident in my care, as I did with fetal medicine. From the bottom of my heart - thank you to you all, and i truly hope you get the recognition you all deserve for your incredible work in a very busy and I am sure a very stressful and challenging department at times.

author: Storygirl81
title: An ultrasound scan for potential breast cancer
body:
I went to the Mermaid Centre at Treliske hospital in Cornwall at the end of December after being referred by doctor to have a lump in my breast examined. The centre there is fantastic and the nurses were all great, but after the initial examination and mammogram I then went in for an ultrasound scan with a staff member who performed the scan; I found them to have some of the worst people skills for a person in that profession that I have ever come across and was truly awful. After examining me for a long time, the first thing they asked was whether I had anyone with me, which immediately made me hysterical.  
They then went on to say that they couldn't see on the scan what it was, and that I'd need biopsies done, but in their opinion it was cancer. Now this was done with no emotion, no care and so matter of fact it really was quite unbelievable. I have since been told by multiple people that they were in no position to be stating this to me as if it was fact, especially as I was informed at the same time that they didn't know what it was. It made me hysterical, and fearful for my life, at a time when it was still unclear what the problem was at all.  
At the time of writing this I still have not have the biopsy results back, 2 weeks later, and am now sitting here fearing the worst. I am due back there next Monday - so 3 weeks after the initial scans etc - and I will be refusing to see that staff member again. I don't want them anywhere near me. I understand that people just have a job to do and can't get emotional about things, but I do feel that there should be a level of care given and that telling someone that they probably have cancer just off the back of a scan and before any results have come through is pretty unacceptable.  
There was no attempt to make me feel better, or even just to say that they weren't sure and were going to do some biopsies just to see what it might be. I found the treatment to be harsh and I feel sorry for anyone else that has to come into contact with this staff member.

author: Jammy999
title: Full sti testing
body: Asymptomatic routine testing post-sex work. Was treated as expected, with dignity and respect. No issues

author: Murf
title: Best service ever
body:
Had a phone appointment within 2 hrs. Examined 2 hrs later and all tests done.  
Best service ever, thanks so much.

author: adnill26
title: I already know that this is the best decision for our future
body:
After just over 2 years of daily heroin use and been stuck in the vicious cycle of addiction we finally found the courage to reach out and ask for the help we desperately needed. Having had a previous, personal, negative experience when asking for help regarding a medical issue I was dubious as to if we would be acknowledged and helped or ignored and left to work it out for ourselves.  
The first contact we has was via email and contained an attachment of 2 referral forms that needed to be completed and returned, one for my partner and the other for myself. Due to the old format of the attachment we were unable to complete and return so I picked up the phone, pushed my anxiety to the side and explained our inability to complete and return the forms but emphasised that we were in desperate need of help.  
Although the person was well spoken, friendly and listened to everything I had to say, their response of I could do it over the phone now but I only have my laptop and I don't think I have a copy on here. Just come in to the Centre tomorrow and speak to the receptionist, did not fill me with much confidence, nor did the staff member putting the phone down on me shortly after finishing this sentence.  
Nonetheless though the next day we walked to 45minutes to the city centre and filled the form out without any issues, within about 10 minutes of completing we were handed our individual, initial appointment cards. The person on reception went out of their way to get us appointments as soon as possible but also at the same time and date so we could be there to support each other.  
All we had to do was make it to the end of December 2021 and we would be on the road to a better, healthier future. Just knowing that there are people who genuinely want to help you and want you to do the best you can is a relief and a blessing in itself. My partner had been a user of this service many years ago and he was apprehensive as he felt he'd let his previous keyworkers down and that they would be disappointed with him, but this was not the case at all.  
One of his old workers actually took the time to come and say hello to both of us as we were waiting to receive our first prescription and reassured us that we'd done one of the hardest things already by coming in, admitting we had a problem and asking for help. As soon as my partner realised there was no disappointment, judgement or negativity you could clearly see the difference in his face, like a weight had been lifted off his shoulders.  
We have our first telephone appointment coming up this coming week and the difference is already amazing. If I can find a way to update you all I will. Anyone who is looking for help for themselves or maybe for a friend or loved one I cannot recommend Fitzwilliam Centre START service enough, they are life-changers and I already know that this is the best decision for our future and that they are going to be there to offer us all the support and any resources we could possibly need to succeed on our journey to become drug free once again.

readBy.name: Sheffield Health and Social Care NHS Foundation Trust

author: Jimpsy
title: Difficult obtaining an appointment with GP
body:
Trying to secure an appointment with the family GP is hard enough but since Covid came around it is impossible to get an appointment with the family doctor without having to relay information like War and Peace to the receptionist. Then have to repeat it again when a member of the triage team call you back, and then to the receptionist when they eventually book an appointment. By the time it is booked the one ailment has turned into 3 or 4 or maybe more.  
I wouldn't like to be needing to speak to my GP urgently, as 3 weeks or more is not urgent and that is because it takes about 3 weeks to actually get an answer when you call them.

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland

author: pelicanhf73
title: Step by step instructions would really help
body:
I have been getting help from the urology department in Barnstaple with a urinary issue. The prescribed treatment is quite difficult to self administer but Lucy who did the first treatment showed me what to do - she said to get in touch if I had difficulty however - she was lovely. I tried the second treatment myself but the medication just went everywhere and the third time I just couldn't do it again.  
I rang Lucy and and she said she could help me that afternoon. The instructions for administering the medication are very long and contain a lot of text. I mentioned to Lucy that it would be so much easier if there were diagrams or step by step pictures which are easier to follow when doing something complicated. She thought it was a good idea and suggested I use Care Opinion to make my suggestion.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: lupusdd78
title: Amazing treatment and staff
body:
I received excellent and speedy medical treatment and I want you to know about it.  
I had been having headaches for a while which was unusual for me and went to the doctor . I had a brain scan at Ninewells Hospital and nothing showed up; false sense of security. The headaches continued and my jaw became sore when eating cereal. I went back to the doctor. This was in December 2018.  
The doctor was brilliant and said I had to go to the Victoria Hospital, Kirkcaldy straight away. She telephoned and the consultant saw me that afternoon. My husband and I were 5 hours in the hospital but we didn’t mind. The staff were amazing and the x-ray team stayed over their finishing time to see to me.  
Since then my follow up treatment in the community has been excellent and I am now in remission.

author: pictordp74
title: Reassuring and kind
body:
All the team from start to finish were so lovely, really reassuring and kind. I was so scared this morning and they all made this experience as good as it could have been.  
Thank you all so much, you are amazing

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: Louise74
title: Prompt and person-centred response
body:
I have recently been diagnosed with breast cancer and I have found the response very quick and person-centred. The Breast Care Nurses have been wonderful in supporting - acknowledging my concerns and not dismissing them, and talking me through both the physical expectations of the treatment I am to have and how this has affected my mental health.  
The information that I have been given is informative and I suppose the only thing is that my diagnosis doesn't just affect me and I would have hoped there was more information for supporting for my children, who are young adults, but are important to me.

author: Wellness warrior
title: Wait for breast clinic appointment
body: My mother attended her Gp in December regarding a lump on her right breast, her appointment at the breast clinic is not until Feburary which is a 50 day wait. She was previously diagnosed with triple negative breast cancer in for which she received chemotherapy, lumpectomy and radiotherapy. This is causing my mother anxiety and I'm concerned about her mental wellbeing as well as physical. I had believed NICE guidelines were that suspected cancer cases should be seen within 14 days from initial consultation with GP. Id think this was more vital when the patient had previously had an aggressive form of cancer.

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland

author: Heacw86
title: Minor injuries Stirling
body: At the end of December my 4 year old took a nasty fall that required his head glued. Minor injuries at Stirling saw us extremely quickly and the lovely Charlie was so amazing with my wee boy. Charlie laughed and joked with him and reassured him that everything was okay. Charlie took extra time to clean the blood from his blond hair as he knew he wouldn’t be able to wash it for 5 days and all the time keeping him happy and entertained with his stories about football. What could have been a very painful and upsetting experience for both myself and my son was made so much easier due to the quick service and fantastic Charlie. My son also received a lovely teddy and has since named him Charlie. Also a shout to the paramedic team who although stretched to the limits managed to keep in contact with us and find us the right place to go without the need for a long wait for an ambulance.

readBy.name: Office of Murdo Fraser, MSP for Mid Scotland & Fife

author: velark97
title: A&E visit
body:
A big shout out for our NHS.  
Spent the day at A&E Hairmyres.  
(All fine, the next bit is the important bit)  
While in the waiting area, I saw people being efficient. Coming and going in a timely fashion. All being treated with respect and care.  
The staff were all kind, courteous and we had a good laugh with them.  
Just magic. Sending all you wonderful NHS love and good cheer. Thank you.

author: userrep
title: Operation for hammer toe
body:
An operation was carried out by Dr Jowett and team on beginning of December at York Hospital.  
What was exceedingly good:  
It was to be carried out using a spinal anaesthetic, which I expected to be painful, but which was administered after a local anaesthetic and was truly painless, as was the operation itself. In theatre, I was surprised and delighted when someone asked if I would like to watch the operation. 'Yes, please!' I replied, hardly able to believe my luck.  
I found the whole procedure, which included chipping out a piece of bone and a wire insert, fascinating. There was no feeling in my leg or foot, which was a weird sensation, especially when they lifted what seemed to be someone else's limb into position. Some people have called me brave, which I don't deserve because I felt completely safe, and because it was only like watching an operation on a dead chicken.  
I would like the whole team and others to know how much this ability to observe and learn meant to me. Being watched by a patient may have felt uncomfortable to some staff, I shall never know, but it was a truly patient-centred, a partnership which contrasted vastly with my medical past. 'Them and Us' morphed together to make 'We'.  
By inviting me to watch they had left themselves vulnerable to criticism of any obvious mistakes that might have occurred. But importantly, by trusting me they had shown me respect. They had treated me as a Person, rather than just some Thing. This insightful, modern attitude continued in the Recovery Room. Sadly, I was unable to access the online Survey about this experience, but I'm writing here because I would like the whole team and others to know how much this good experience meant to me. It showed a degree of the team's self confidence, which in turn boosted my confidence in them and contributed towards a fruitful staff/patient relationship.  
I know I need to get out more, but this hospital experience was a highlight in my week!  
[Unsure about 'Staff attitude']  
[Unsure about 'Staff skills']

readBy.name: York Teaching Hospital NHS foundation Trust

author: moongx74
title: Contraceptive pill
body: I spoke to someone about accessing the contraceptive pill and recieved informative and helpful advice as to which one to take. Staff were very friendly and easy to speak to.

author: GM91
title: Speech Struggles
body:
I contacted my GP as I was struggling with my speech and was referred to the Adult Community Speech & Language Therapy Service for East Lothian and Midlothian.  
I dealt with Lucy who is a Speech & Language Therapist and received an extremely high level of support, guidance and advice to help manage my speech issues. Lucy always took the time to understand exactly how I was feeling, trying to identify the root cause of my specific issue and provided numerous exercises to help me deal with this on a day to day basis. We held regular catch ups to check-in on progress and on each occasion, Lucy was very easy to speak to and enabled me to be totally open and honest - something I have struggled with previously regarding my speech problems. At times she was simply a sounding board for me which helped me emotionally deal with things but she always had ideas and suggestions to help me manage my problem going forward.  
I thoroughly enjoyed working with Lucy and am very thankful that she was appointed as my speech therapist. Thank you Lucy!

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland

author: cafebw98
title: District nursing team
body: I am really unhappy with the response from my district nursing team. I contacted my doctors surgery today to ask for a nurse to come and give me a b12 booster. I am unable to get to the surgery because I have a double ankle fracture and a lisfranc fracture. I’m currently on week 10 of recovery and although I’m practicing partially weight bearing I am still very much house bound. The reply from nursing was that because I can walk and because I get to hospital appointments they won’t see me. I am very disappointed by this response and feel that there is a complete lack of care and compassion. I am unable to drive and my husband works full time and we have two young children. I would not be requesting this care if I didn’t need it.

author: Jadeymcc
title: amazing maternity care.
body: I have had all of my children in the maternity and every time they are outstanding! I had one natural water birth and a following two c sections and the care and devotion from the staff is amazing! Will never forget the care and support I received nothing was to much for them! Forever thankful!

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: Joetom
title: My uncle,s care
body: My elderly uncle was admitted to the Mater hospital in April and the care he received was exceptional from all staff on the ward although he was on a covid ward ( he didn't have covid ) I was able to visit him regularly as he was on end of life care.After he died their bereavement team contacted me on a number of occasions to see how I was. His last days were very peaceful and I was grateful for that as the care he received in 3 weeks in a nursing home hadn't been.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: SueW57
title: Excellent drive through service
body: Excellent drive through service at the Keepmoat stadium. Don't even have to get out of the car

author: Aoiyf36
title: professional staff
body: Staff in this unit (Blossom Unit) are 10/10 as the care they are giving to my child is just great as he loves it, as well as the attention he is getting from all them. They are so gentle and kind with him and it’s great to see the smiles they are bringing to his face, he just lights up anytime one of the nurses come into see him. They are always checking in on us which is great and making sure that he is okay, the staff have been very professional and mannerly towards us honesty cannot think of anything negative to say about this unit even the food and cleanliness has been great. Thank you to Craigavon Area Hospital Staff, you are all amazing.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: uttershill
title: Fantastic hospital at home service
body:
In November my wife became very ill with no obvious cause. She was 80 at the time and our GP referred her to the Midlothian/NHS Hospital at Home team. A doctor and three nurses arrived within a short space of time and gave her a long and full examination. This was followed up the next day by a visit from two doctors who said the tests had been OK for the most part and handed her over to their Physio team. Unfortunately she suffered a mild TIA that night. The Hospital at Home Doctor organised an emergency brain scan at Edinburgh Royal Infirmary and this was followed up by a phone call then a visit from Dr. Cantley, the Hospital at Home consultant and Dr Sylvester.  
Dr. Cantley was a little concerned about the possibility of Parkinson's Disease and arranged a consultation with a Parkinson's specialist. This will take place tomorrow, but last Thursday my wife became ill again and again the Hospital at Home team took over and again she has been seen daily by Hospital at Home nurses  
We cannot begin to explain how impressed we have been by the Hospital at Home service and how grateful we are. They are doing a fantastic job.

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland

author: Aoiyf36
authorRole: a staff member posting for a carer/relative
title: Brilliant treatment for my child
body:
My child is in Craigavon Area Hospital at the moment and suffering from dehydration as they are unable to eat and drink much.Following a lot of scans to see what the problem was they were able to confirm that it was appendicitis. The doctor was amazing as he was able to explain to me what this was and what the treatment process was going to look like. My child had to go into surgery and I feel this is a scary moment in any mothers life having to put your child through this, but it had to be done for him to get better.  
The whole time I felt so nervous and anxious but there was one nurse who was so lovely and kind as she came over to me and comforted me about the whole situation. I forget her name but she was so down to earth. She saw that I hadn’t eaten much all day and brought me down some tea, sandwiches and biscuits which was such a lovely gesture and lifted my spirits a bit.  
I have never been so glad to see my child as thankfully the surgery went brilliantly, so he is just in recovery mode at the moment. I would like to take this opportunity to thank the doctors and nurses so much for what they have done, this is very much appreciated and will never be forgotten!

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

title: Amazing practice, staff/doctors and care
body:
The support, care and professionalism I've received from Altrincham Medical Practice has been second to none. 
All of the team have gone above and beyond to provide help and flexibility when I received a shock diagnosis. This has allowed me to focus on myself, knowing that I was receiving the best care and medication.

title: Outstanding
body: My daughter missed her flu spray at school due to being ill. The Managing Partner at the Limes Epping replied to my email on a Sunday evening which I thought was unbelievable and she booked me an appointment by phone for the morning after I called. Extremely caring and professional. Couldn't ask for more. Thank you

author: Dartmoor
title: Prostate Biopsy
body:
I firstly saw Dr Zang, a Consultant Surgeon (Urology), at Newton Abbot Hospital outpatients clinic, for examination following referral by my GP. I had just had my MRI scan at Torbay hospital prior to this initial consultation.  
When the results of the MRI scan became known, Dr Zang advised I have a prostate biopsy as a precautionary measure.  
I want to express my sincere thanks to Dr Zhang and her team for their care, concern and professional skills during my procedure. When I walked into the day surgery unit, I was immediately made to feel reassured, and the registration could not have been better. When I walked into the theatre and saw a team of 5, I suddenly realised the biopsy is not an insignificant procedure, but it was conducted so efficiently and with minimal fuss, the stress levels were massively reduced. In hindsight the biopsy is a gruesome experience and as the day approached for my admission, I was becoming more tense. Not sure whether online video depictions of the procedure helped or not. Anyway it is now done, my recovery has been without problems and I move on. A massive thanks to them all. They are wonderful people.

readBy.name: Torbay and South Devon NHS Foundation Trust

title: Warmth, compassion and excellence
body:
I was in hospital with my 6 week baby who had Broncilitus between Christmas and New Year. 
My experience (in A&E and once admitted to Rainbow Ward) of the nurses, ward sisters, doctors, receptionists, cleaning and catering staff was outstanding. 
The staff were all warm and sensitive during a very difficult time and took care to explain everything whilst carrying out complex, intricate procedures on a tiny baby. We were regularly checked on, never left to worry and always knew when we would next be seen  or receive treatment or support.
There is one female doctor who exuded confidence and carried out a procedure which I think prevented further interventions and the nurses (many of whom had only recently qualified) were also clearly well supported by their leaders - able to make decisions and carry out their work with precision. 
It is particularly amazing when you think about the pressure the staff have been under in the last two years. Many of the paediatric nurses had to treat adults when Covid struck and have worked dilligently in some of the hardest times the NHS have ever faced. They are a credit to Newham hospital and should be celebrated and showcased at every opportunity.

title: Excellent care
body:
Rushed into A and E when I collapsed in the street . 
Could not fault the care  . Speed of treatment and total professionalism of staff . Looked after with patience and good humour . 
Please thank all staff on Aand E and AMU ward . They were all very busy but took time to explain everything to me and looked after me so well . Thank you .

author: scorpiusbb53
title: I feel let down by mental health services
body:
I was diagnosed bipolar after marrying and moving here in 1983. I have 2 children and suffered with terrible post natal depression.  
In 1981 I had my son and on my birthday I was sectioned to a psychiatric hospital for the first time in Dartford, Kent. I received ECT treatment and almost gave my children up for adoption.  
In 1983 I married my second husband and the mental health system for Sittingbourne has been atrocious. I am now 66 years old and I feel my life has been wasted. I was unable to pursue a career even though I had a good Grammar School education in Dartford, Kent.  
Now I am a widow and able to take out private medical insurance so that I get proper care when I feel poorly.

readBy.name: Kent and Medway NHS and Social Care Partnership Trust

title: Excellent patient care
body: Called in today to ask about having a flu jab. Ten minutes later the vaccination had been administered thanks to a very helpful receptionist & nurse. Brilliant service again from Kenmore - thank you!

title: Top practice
body:
I have visited quite a few times now, this time I was there for an ECG   
I was in quick even though it was very busy, the Doctors and Nurses there are all very nice and efficient. It's always clean, when I was there last a person who was not wearing a mask was asked politely to leave which he did. I wish all supermarkets also did this.

author: ZoeR
title: Fantastic team
body: Paul and Barbara couldn't be better. I came for my first vaccine and they put me so at ease, had a laugh and not stressed or panicked. They gave me the required information and more. I got my injection and didn't even feel it. (I hate needles). I couldn't have asked for a better pair. Fantastic team

title: Staff very efficient
body: I would like to thank the doctors and nurses in the A&E paediatric unit for there services that they gave to my daughter this evening 4/1/22 such a wonderful team.

title: Outstanding Maternity Care
body:
I changed my maternity care to Chesterfield for several reasons and it was without a doubt the best decision. I live out of area but was happy to travel. There is always parking and the location of the hospital is easy to get to. 
I work also work for the NHS in the community services for children and young people so understand how challenging it can be to provide high quality care at this time and was ready to ‘overlook’ minor issues however this was never necessary because there weren’t ANY issues. And nothing was ‘just acceptable’ but very much outstanding. 
The online maternity notes were helpful meaning I could access my information, see updates, send questions regarding my pregnancy at any time which were promptly responded to. 
The antenatal clinics always had a very calm environment and every staff member I encountered was friendly, smiling, polite, professional and helpful. I felt listened to, encouraged and included in the decisions of my care.
The maternity ward was again a very calm and surprisingly quiet environment. The ward seemed full of patients and staff shortages but remained calm and nothing was too much trouble. All staff went above in the care provision. 
My son had a tongue tie picked up with the first 15 minutes of his birth and an appointment was provided within a week which seemed reasonable to me given current waiting times elsewhere. One maternity support worker wasn’t satisfied with this (aware of the problems that would arise for my son and also myself breastfeeding) and persisted in her communication with colleagues which meant a tongue division was completed the morning after he was born. He could feed well and I avoided painful breastfeeding issues because of it.
My stay was during the winter and peak of staff off sick with coronavirus (as highlighted in the news) but at no point did staff mention, complain or use this as an excuse which is incredible as they would of had every right to explain this. They smiled and kept the focus on the mother’s and newborns, ensuring that everyone’s experience remained personal. Nothing was rushed and I felt completely cared for and supported in caring for my baby. Every staff member contributed to that calm environment and kept a high level of professionalism whilst showing compassion and also a friendly atmosphere not only towards the patients but also to each other which is probably why it felt so relaxed to stay there. 
So to everyone at the Royal in Maternity services (and also in theatres for the c section) thank you endlessly!! Incredible honest, kind and professional care. A complete example to other hospitals of how it can be done in the face of current endless challenges. A very positive experience at a special time that I will remember forever and tell everyone about.

readBy.name: Chesterfield Royal Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

author: Brenda21
title: Not all heroes wear capes
body:
My child was admitted to Picu on three separate occasions, including twice during a 4 month stay in the hospital.  
The last admission as an outpatient was in November with bronchiolitis. They were transferred from the Blossom hospital in Craigavon and sedated and put on a ventilator before being transferred back to the Blossom nearly a week later.  
The team in Picu have always been amazing, from the crash team who provided transfer, the staff throughout our stays. They went above and beyond for our family. Each nurse/doctor did everything to ensure my child was always comfortable and that we were supported too. The team is made up of outstanding nurses and doctors that could not do more than they already are doing. Not all heroes wear capes. They wear tunics & overalls.  
Picu environment can be daunting for any parent so having that bond with the team makes any stay a little less stressful.  
We always had full trust in the Picu!  
Forever grateful for the care provided.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust
Southern Health and Social Care Trust
Plymouth University, Faculty of Health and Human Sciences

title: Great doctor
body: Lady gp I saw today very thorough and caring did not rush consultation and assured me I would receive a call at a later date to review my health and medication.Very lovely lady cannot praise her enough.On leaving she wished me well and enquired after my partner which I thought was great shame I am not allowed to mention her name but I understand why

title: Very good
body:
Having my breather medication changed by the new Chemist for a generic brand 

Literally caused me some grief. 
I rang the surgury and had a phone consultation same day
My old medication sent hours later
 
Good work can’t fault it.
BTW, any chance you can consider putting “Press 1 to skip Covid warning” 
Listening to that every time you ring is a pain

title: Amazing service
body: I attended the hospital due to a fall. The accident and emergency department was extremely busy. The charge nurse I saw was absolutely fantastic. The nurse practitioner was also amazing and the plaster team. The service I received was brilliant and couldn’t have had any better if private.

title: Brilliant physio diagnostics and advice
body:
Attended yesterday regarding severe problems with my right hand.
I received a clear explanation of what was wrong and detailed exercises to alleviate the symptoms.
I believe the person treated me went the extra mile to help me understand the problems, help me to understand and master the exercises required and to refer me on to the next stage of treatment.
 I am delighted to say that doing these exercises this morning there were two little clicks and my forefinger joint went back into place.
This has restored my forefinger/thumb action back to normal and the pain in the hand is reducing!
This may not sound much but after 7 months of pain and inconvenience, this is a brilliant result.
I am very grateful for the treatment and for the high level of care and attention I received.
JohnP

title: Very helpful receptionist
body: I just spoke to a receptionist about a couple of non-urgent but pressing issues and she was very helpful and knowledgable. She gave me expert advice on both things, and booked my an appointment with a physiotherapist without me needing to see a GP. I had been nervous about calling as I know they are extremely busy at the moment but I need not have been as she was very kind and gave me all the time I needed.

title: Excellent staff
body: The treatment during my stay in hospital was excellent. The staff were very professional and put me at ease. I have been a few times now and I have been very impressed with the unsung heroes on the front desk who help people F2F and on the phone clearly put people at ease when they are worried tense. Well done

readBy.name: Hull University Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust

title: Great Practice
body: The care I have received from this practice has been absolutely fabulous. Throughout these exceptional times they have maintained high standards. They are a shining example of what a GP practice should be about. They have not joined the GP super-partnership that operates primary health care and community services nationally. I have had the opportunity to witness the decline in services and patient experience in one of these practices. All I can say is a huge thank you to Dynley House Surgery for all the extra work you do.

author: PBr
title: Wonderful staff and fantastic care
body: I was in Queen Elizabeth hospital over Christmas having renal cancer surgically removed robotically. I spent 4 days in HDU one over the Christmas holiday and I would like to thank all of the wonderful staff for their fantastic care. In particular I wish to pass on my great appreciation to Tess, Kerry and Julie for the thoughtful care and compassion they showed during this difficult time. They are truly a credit to the NHS and I can’t thank them enough for their care.

title: Exceptional service and company
body:
I have been having oxygen delivered by Baywater for 2 months. I feel like the service I receive is like one that you pay privately at a hefty monthly premium.

The first delivery I was on the school run and left a note asking please could they wait until I got home not expecting them to at all as I know they’ll be busy. I got home and they were waiting! The man was extremely helpful explaining how to use the equipment and reorder. 

Each time I’ve had any contact since, every person I’ve spoken to is very friendly, professional and goes out of their way to help. They accommodate any request I’ve asked for and stick to it. Their staff are brilliant.

Baywater are a breath of fresh air as a company. So many should take a leaf out of their books!

Ashleigh Todd

title: Great service
body:
My husband today had an appointment at Audiology to have his hearing aids tested.
He was full of praise and compliments of both the staff he saw.
Well done audiology at QEH.
So impressed with their helpfulness and understanding of problems he had with his hearing aids.

readBy.name: The Queen Elizabeth Hospital Kings Lynn NHS Foundation Trust

title: Outstanding practice
body:
Very efficient and professional. Lovely doctors empathetic and proactive . I have used 4 surgeries in leicestershire this is the best by far.
Despite the lack of face to face visits at the minute the doctor I go to is very much on the ball and keeps notes of our last discussion and involves me in the decision making of my care.

title: Helpful
body: I rang up spoke to receptionist she was really friendly and put me through to the doctor he was really friendly and dealt with my problem straight away .. thank you

title: Wonderful caring staff
body:
My mother was admitted after a fall which split open the fragile skin on her arm in 3 places and looked like something out of a horror film (to me anyway!) 
From start to finish, the staff at the hospital - receptionist, ambulance driver who got her a wheelchair when she overheard what was happening and all the staff in the UTC were brilliant. They were all friendly, cheerful, caring and quick with their duties. We were seen, helped and on our way home within an hour, which was important as my mother had large open wounds which needed to be treated quickly to avoid infection etc. 
We can’t thank the staff enough for our experience at the hospital and we would like to say a BIG thank you for the amazing work they are doing, especially in the difficult circumstances of the continuing pandemic.

author: Tom2022
title: Inner Space - my first NHS Hospital experience
body:
Just an ordinary Sunday night and nothing exciting on the telly, again. Not feeling too great anyway, so I’ll best be hitting bed early with a hot drink.  
Then it comes, hits my chest like a wave of lead, leaves me breathless, reeling, fearful of more too come. Get the phone while I still can. Just me on my own these days, and these past few months have taught me to be prepared, self sufficient, less fearful of the unexpected...  
But this whooshing sensation inside has “fearful” written all over it, all coiled and taut, perhaps to hint at worse to come? There are times when to hesitate can save face later. This isn’t one of those.  
I make the call.  
Twenty minutes later two ninja medics whirl around my room, set up some gear, reassure me with their purposeful presence before taking in my data - telemetry, they call it. Blood pressure and heart rate: not quite as explosive as I’d feared, I’m glad to hear, but deffo worth a closer look, they reckon in that bulletproof pleasantness that I’ll get to meet very up-close and again and again these next three days.  
Once strapped into the ambulance heading for Perth and having a wee chat with the medic, that crushing pressure inside me has almost lifted and I feel a bit of a fraud to be honest. But once through A&E things become clearer. That punch I’d felt had indeed been a heart attack, albeit a minor one. So, good call, after all.  
It’s nearly 3 AM by the time they wheel me up to the HDU - high-dependency unit. But you wouldn’t know it. The nurses are engaging, wide-awake, and happy to hear my backstory all over again, understanding of my frazzlement with all that’s washed over me these past three hours. I tell them this is my first ever overnight stint in hospital - honestly - and they smile politely, not least by way of offering me tea. Sure, they’ve seen it all, and often. But that doesn’t make any of them seem bored. I drift off at last, to the polite chimes of overhead vitals monitors, four in this room alone, hi-tech, just like you see in the movies. The one above me displays my very own name. Which, for so many reasons, has me weep, quietly.  
Tests, tea and talk, the latter much needed by me after my boring Sunday that never was. All part of the reliable undercarriage to bear my hopes and fears through two uncertain days. And then, reasonably good news: the angiogram (quite the cyber-busting procedure involving long thin wires and tiny tubes to scrub and repair damaged heart arteries) had worked well, and together with a cornucopia of pills should restore my 61-year-old ticker back to near-normal for its age. My relief - their reward. And yes, it’s massive, for all of us.  
I write this wee story reclining on my trusty ward bed and awaiting a taxi to take me home. It’ll feel a little different, my home, I’m guessing, now that I’ll see it with slightly wider eyes. And for that and much besides I’d like to very much thank the unflappable nurses and doctors at Perth Royal Infirmary and Dundee’s Ninewell Hospital (angiogram), as well as the indefatigable ambulance teams who ferried me through this unexpected inner-space adventure. Special thanks to Stewart, Denise, Yvonne, Kevin, Christi, and not least Ashley - you all know who you are. Vorsprung durch Technik, but with a smile!

title: Amazing
body: Can I just say a massive thank as a female doctor put me on terbinafine tablets after dermatology confirmed my fungal nail infection the tablets have cleared infection after many years of negative fungal nail lab tests when it was positive for fungus

title: Amazing
body: Can I just say a massive thank as a female doctor put me on terbinafine tablets after dermatology confirmed my fungal nail infection the tablets have cleared infection after many years of negative fungal nail lab tests when it was positive for fungus

title: Amazing
body: Can I just say a massive thank as a female doctor put me on terbinafine tablets after dermatology confirmed my fungal nail infection the tablets have cleared infection after many years of negative fungal nail lab tests when it was positive for fungus

title: Amazing
body: Can I just say a massive thank as a female doctor put me on terbinafine tablets after dermatology confirmed my fungal nail infection the tablets have cleared infection after many years of negative fungal nail lab tests when it was positive for fungus

title: Excellent
body: Been absolutely fab throughout the whole pandemic. Always had an appointments when needed and always been seen in person when necessary. I have my preferred doctors as anyone would anywhere they go.  I feel very lucky to be registered at this practice as many other people ive spoken to haven’t had this exceptional service at their own practices.

title: Excellent  Service
body: Over the  last year I  have had to visit and speak with  the  surgery  on many occasions, and from reception , nurses and Doctors  I   would  honestly say its  the best  service  I have received from  any  doctors surgery    I have been  with..    many thanks

title: Pneumococcal vaccine - feedback
body: There’s no sticker, no badge, no record card to prove it, not even a plaster, but I’ve just had my pneumococcal vaccine, and I’m feeling very pleased and so grateful to the surgery. Thank you so much.

title: Very helpful friendly staff
body: I went for an ENT appointment and the staff were very friendly and fixed my blocked ears! No pain and knew I was in safe hands.

author: Orthonurse
title: Outstanding care for hip replacement surgery
body:
I want to express my gratitude for the excellent care I received during my admission on the 10th December 2021 for a total hip replacement at Wrightington hospital under the care of Mr Clayson .  
Every member of staff I came across introduced themselves and were kind and professional.  
I’ve been a nurse for 35 years and it was an experience to be a patient on the receiving end of excellent care ( albeit very scary !).  
From Mr Clayson’s secretary , via pre op , admission on the orthopaedic unit to theatres and recovery on A ward every member of staff were an asset to this hospital.  
The hospital itself is extremely clean , the food was great and nothing was too much trouble .  
The only criticism would be the total lack of WiFi ! Meaning the poor nurses , as if they haven’t got enough to do , we’re running around passing patients the ward phone . Relatives / visitors were not permitted therefore were anxious to hear from us . It’s a new wing to the hospital therefore difficult to understand why this happens ?  
If this could be improved it would be a faultless service .  
I would recommend Mr Clayson , his team and the hospital for outstanding care .

readBy.name: Wrightington, Wigan and Leigh NHS Trust

links.id: frustrated with lack of signal and wifi

title: I’m so happy with this practice.
body: I have recently been unwell and I am so proud to say that this surgery worked efficiently, and professionally.

title: Very understanding
body: Very understanding reception, as well as all members of staf including all GPs who listen and are very thorough, extremely supportive and could not recommend more to anybody.

title: Always a thorough appointment
body: Whenever I have had an appointment with the doctors here they are very thorough especially with children and babies so I always feel extremely confident my family are in safe hands here

title: Excellent Service Provided
body: I have to compliment all the staff in the Urology clinic I attended today. All staff were welcoming, friendly, helpful and extremely professional as they went about there duties. I could not have wished for better care on the day. I arrived early was seem promptly and I was walking out of Lister just over an hour later. Absolutely excellent, well done to all of you and thankyou.

title: excellent practice
body: i have had a very successful cataract operation to my right eye, and have had great feed back from Specsavers on my 4 weeks follow up appointment on how good my eyesight is now. both my wife and myself are really happy for the way Spanedica treat cataracts.

title: An outstanding GP practice
body: St Peter's has been our family GP for many years.  They are truly outstanding and the staff work incredibly hard to provide a very high level of service and always go the extra mile. We have always been seen when needed including urgent appointments.  How lucky we feel to have such a wonderful GP practice. Thank you!

title: Best Doctors Surgery
body: Every experience I have had with Bridgewater Surgeries have been amazing from start to finish. Every doctor and nurse I have seen have been friendly, caring and had a bit of banter with me. Visiting the doctors really triggers my anxiety and they make me feel at ease every single time. They are all so caring and are amazing at what they do. Even the receptionists deserve a shoutout, they get bombarded with calls every day but still remain happy and positive over the phone and in person! Thank you for making me feel so at ease and for being absolute stars ⭐️

author: Septbirth
title: Negative induction experience
body:
My experience at PRM leading up to the induction was very positive. I saw different midwives and doctors each time but felt I was in safe hands.  
I was induced at 39 weeks due to my age (I'd also had a day of monitoring the baby for a high heart rate at my 38 week appointment, so although it was just an active baby, it made me more agreeable to induction). I'd had two natural births previously and wanted it to be as natural as possible so opted for the outpatient balloon method. This went well, everything was clearly explained and the doctor checked I was okay throughout. I was even offered gas for the discomfort (which I didn't need).  
At home I experienced contractions and cramping and around midnight the balloon fell out. I called maternity assessment who were lovely and supportive and agreed that I would try to get some sleep as my waters hadn't gone yet and to keep my appointment to have my waters broken. In the morning my mucus plug had come away but I didn't have contractions or a loss of waters so attended the induction ward for my appointment.This is where I feel that things started to go wrong as the original plan changed and not really for any medical need for me or my baby but more due to staffing/ how busy they were. Firstly the doctor was delayed due to an emergency (fair enough), and then when a doctor did examine me they said that although they could break my waters but there wasn't space for me in the labour ward. So, they were just going to give me Prostin gel as I was there anyway and it would help shorten my cervix more. They didn't give me the option to go home and come back (which might have been better given there was no space in the labour ward for me - so why put me into labour?). I didn't know much about the gel because it wasn't part of my induction plan so I didn't know it could cause hyperstimulation and this wasn't explained to me either. Just over an hour later I was experiencing hyperstimulation as I was contracting with less than a minute apart. I asked the midwife if this was normal as in my previous labours they weren't as close together and as strong until I was close to giving birth. They said they could be Prostin contractions and could ease off. I wasn't put on the monitor which might have shown what they were like. In fact at no other point during the next five hours in the induction ward was my baby's heart rate monitored. Despite intense contractions lasting 45 seconds and 20 seconds apart. I found this concerning because everything I've read about hyperstimulation says that the heart rate should be monitored. At the time however I didn't know this was unusual, my concern was around the horrific pain I was struggling to cope with and whether I was going to make it to the labour ward to give birth- there was one point in the toilet that I was sure I was going to give birth there, and the pressure and frequency of the contractions made me feel out of control (like the feeling of transition in my previous labours). I told the midwife of my concerns because in my first labour I needed to send my husband to look for a midwife when I needed to push and my second labour was 2 and a half hours long despite being back to back. I found the pain from this labour far worse than my previous labours but managed to get pain relief that made those births manageable. I was only able to have one dihydrocodeine tablet and two paracetamol on the induction ward. This really didn't feel enough to help me stay in control. I felt I was almost hyperventilating, my body was shaking, I was sobbing with tears streaming down my face uncontrollably, and this escalated to screaming where I could not stop myself - all in a ward where the other patients and their partners could hear. I felt that I was probably going to have to give birth there and despite being in this state I felt I was still not a priority for the labour ward. As whilst I was hysterical like this a midwife came to collect another patient who was ahead of me in the queue - they were not in active labour and were able to chat away and walk off with them. Whilst I don't know their circumstances, it really didn't help me to see that. Eventually the midwife agreed to examine me ( They had been reluctant to earlier) but did so at around 7.40pm - they found I was 4cm dilated. Just after 8pm I was taken to the labour ward (labour ward midwives were great) I able to have gas and air and my baby monitored (though their heart rate dropped and I had to move onto my side). My waters were bugling and when they were broken everything intensified. I was about to be given morphine , I'd been begging for an epidural, but it turned out to be too late as I rapidly dilated from 5cm to 10cm in around ten minutes. I have never felt pain like this in my life - I didn't think it could get any worse and I remember feeling like I could die from the pain. Fortunately though as soon as I was fully dilated I gave birth in one push (I don't think I could have stopped it to be honest). our baby was born within 30 minutes of getting to the labour ward and I was in shock with a 2nd degree tear. Mentally I have struggled to come to terms with this birth experience even though we are both okay- the fear of what could have happened to my baby, the lack of control/autonomy and pain that I experienced.

readBy.name: Office of Clare Haughey, MSP for Rutherglen

title: Shocking customer service, always at “full…
body: Whenever I try booking an appointment, I am very rudely told to ring back at 8am the following day. They are always fully booked and have no empathy whatsoever for the patients. As per 111’s instructions, I’m told to consult my go, but unfortunately this is impossible at limelight. Sometimes when I have left messages on ‘Ask my GP” I don’t get a response for days. I am strongly considering changing practices.

title: Highly professional service.
body: I called on the first working day of the new year, 4/1/2022. I had to wait a long time before the call was answered but I understand this was due to a massive number of calls. I was very concerned about what appeared to be a carcinoma that had developed on my wife's shoulder. The receptionist was highly efficient and professional and understood my concern and recognised the urgency. Within a minute I had received a link which I could send a photo to and 30 minutes later had a call from a doctor and an appointment was arranged for an examination. Extremely quick and professional response by both the doctor and receptionist, (name fed back to the practice at the time) during a very busy and difficult time. Well done!!

title: Cataract surgery
body: 4 weeks after my surgery, I visited my optician, who discovered cystoid macular odeoma in my left eye.  I was seen in clinic on 4/12/21 and prescribed maxidex and acular drops for 6 weeks and told to see my optician after this time.  I am unable to see my optician until 27/1/2022.  I am concerned that the drops may not have reduced the swelling.  Also,  I have already paid £69 to my optician for my appointment on 2nd December and wonder if it would be possible to be referred back to the Eye Clinic at the hospital, who I feel have an obligation to follow up my treatment, so that I  will not have to pay another £69, which if the treatment has not been successful will entail another referral back to the eye clinic to decide what treatment needs to be followed.  I am a retired lady living  on a fixed income, and feel that as this condition is a direct result of cataract surgery, I should reasonably expect to be referred back to the hospital who performed the surgery, rather than having to pay twice to see my optician, who may have to re-refer me back to the eye clinic.

title: Awful Practice
body: Aggressive, patronising and dismissive. Lack of support for the last 8 months with on-going health issues. Sent from pillar to post, spoken to by all members of staff rudely and aggressively, not listened to and lied to. I feel let down from this surgery.

title: Poor diagnostic, impossible to get face to face…
body: My daughter has found it impossible to get a proper diagnosis from a GP as the only way to contact the surgery is through an online form.  First callback prescribed a cream she then had to pay for (she is 18 and at university and the NHS website states she doesnot have to pay til she gets to 19). Cream didn’t work, submitted second form, second phone call prescribes a new cream. This time not paid for. This hasn’t worked. Today the whole process is repeated and again a phone call diagnosis in which I overheard the GP ask “and so what would you like to do next?” She is prescribed a third cream and requests bloods, and again has to pay. She also gets a swab test kit which comes with no instructions.  I showed the dispensary the NHS wording making her exempt from paying and the GP in the dispensary argued with me. We could not get a refund as she paid by Apple Pay. I cannot recommend this surgery, we recently moved and never need the doctors but this experience has been terrible. I dread to think what is happening for people with serious illness.

title: appalling patient care
body: waited in the cumberland centre for 6-7hours without being seen, people who came in a couple hours after me got seen within 2 hours. i myself work within the organisation and know the stresses we face but i was always under the impression that you get seen in the order you arrived, unless you’re an emergency.

title: Great Practice
body:
I hear people ripping apart this surgery, I have no problem with the surgery they provide a  good medical service. If your ill and need to speak to a doctor and your given the telephone consultation then your problem is deal with i cant see the problem if its dealt with that way.  You don't need to see a doctor to be treated. If i've needed to be seen f2f its because i needed a physical examination.  
Please just think about this before you put in writing a bad comment with regards to the doctors surgery. The staff are also under a lot of pressure as in most workplaces now, therefore i would never give the staff a bad time.

title: Excellent service
body: I visited the Redlands Orthopaedic department for my appointment on 30th December 2021. I was greeted by a very pleasant receptionist. I was called through for my appointment within 5 minutes. I was treated by a very pleasant and competent nurse. And very well looked after. In all it was a very pleasant experience.

title: Wonderful service and standard of care
body: I had a worrying issue (unidentified lump in breast tissue) and was particularly anxious about waiting times. I used e-consult at 9am, filled out a form giving some basic details, got a text at lunchtime to say I had been triaged and the doctor would call me between 2 and 4. The doctor did indeed call me shortly after 2, after a short telephone conversation she said that she believed there was nothing to worry about but because of my anxiety invited me in, I was there within half an hour and by half 3 I had been seen and reassured. I cannot imagine being able to get a better or more thorough service. Everyone at the surgery, reception staff and medical staff, were all faultlessly polite and friendly. I understand some people get frustrated that the telephone lines can be busy but given how easy it is to use e-consult I don't think I'll ever be calling again!

title: Rude receptionists
body: My husband had an appointment today. Both A & E and Outpatient department receptionists were very rude to us. We are both exempt from wearing face masks but wore full face shields. Upon arrival we were barked at that we had to wear masks. Trying to force us to wear them otherwise no entry. Even one of these receptionists had hers round her neck! Both receptionists in both departments and security staff made our visit most distressing. They need to learn people person care. Absolutely disgraceful behaviour. I might just add that both my husband and I are fully vaccinated plus booster and sanitised our hands on arrival today

title: Very rude staff
body: I rang up to ask for waiting times, as I’m in too much pain to wait a long time, the receptionist was so rude and said “if I want to be seen I’ll wait like everyone else” in a rude tone. And then cut the call off

title: Really positive experience
body: I do not usually write reviews. However, my experience was really positive. Every single member of staff was amazing and made a challenging situation 10X easier from reception to recovery. I want to thank all the staff for being understanding and sympathetic. The receptionist was incredibly lovely and welcoming which instantly started it off on a good note and the nurse assessing me answered any questions i had for her and was really bubbly and easy to talk too. The theatre team were absolutely incredible and made me feel at ease as soon as i entered the room despite being clearly nervous and in a lot of pain. Despite it being an intrusive procedure the nurse and surgeon made sure my dignity was kept at all times. In recovery they were extremely kind and chatty with a nice cup of tea and biscuits at the ready (still not sure how i ended up in the chair after the procedure) but i woke up with 2 heat pads and a blanket round me. A really really positive experience

title: Spam
body: 4 spam texts; 3 spam calls; never available to book appointments; will use your number for marketing without any possibility to unsubscribe

title: Great practice
body: I can highly commend the staff and doctors at this practice.  They have looked after my family and I for a number of years.

title: Amazing doctors and nurses - EDU ward
body: My own gp misdiagnosed my daughter and failed to give her the care she needed. I brought her to a&e to which we was seen by triage and doctor within 15 minutes. All staff very pleasant. We was then moved to EDU ward and every nurse/doctor who we seen was amazing. They all made us feel so welcome and comfortable. We was there for nearly 24 hours and my daughter now has a diagnosis and the right medication. Amazing staff!

readBy.name: Alder Hey Children's NHS Foundation Trust

title: faultless
body: I was seen by two separate departments last year. both were punctual, had all my records to hand, and were  polite and helpful.

title: Helpful Reception Team
body: I wanted to thank the helpful reception team with my Covid Pass issue, it wasn't something they could fix, but they explained the process and also went above and beyond with the discussion and suggestions (at the very end of the day on the 23rd of December before they broke up for the holidays).  They showed understanding and consideration; I know they really tried to help - it goes a long way.  Thanks again.

title: uncaring for elderly patients
body:
My 81-year-old mother telephoned to request a call for a GP (it did not matter who), was informed by the receptionist that a doctor would call that day. My mother waited by her landline phone until 18:30 with no call from the doctor. On previous occasions, I have used on her behalf the askmygp application, so the following day opened the app and found a message informing my mother someone would phone in 3 days. I reviewed the information which had been submitted by someone unknown to either my mother or myself and found it greatly understated her illness. My points of concern are:
1. why use a method of communication not instigated by the patient, or inform the patient to look at the application for updates? (when I use the application I always state it is on behalf of someone) 
2. the clinical information entered was not correct, is this information entered by a clinically trained person able to interpret what the patient is saying? if the information is transcribed all details should be entered not the high lights as important information is missing.
This is only the latest disappointing care interaction's with Tower Healthcare I would move my mother to another GP practice but unfortunately Tower Healthcare have the monopoly within walking distance for my mother.
Hughly disappointed in the ability to access care.

title: Frustrated again
body:
My daughter regularly seems to get tonsillitis, a week or so before Christmas she was prescribed some antibiotics again and told to ring for a follow up prescription if the problem had not gone away completely when she had finished the tablets. As suggested she contacted the practice again and she spoke to a different doctor, he refused to give her another prescription, sure enough the tonsillitis came back again. Early in the new year she developed a sore throat again, the first day after the bank holiday at the earliest opportunity she tried to ring again for an appointment, she rang continuously for some considerable time and as usual it took a long period until she could actually speak to a receptionist, she was told no appointments were available that day and to ring at 8 in the morning as it was not possible to prebook appointments. She had to go to work the next day so I rang on her behalf, I began ringing just before 8 and managed to get through quickly, however the receptionist couldn’t hear me and after two hellos hung up!
It then took in excess of 50 attempts redialling  to get through to the first message when you have the option to book an appointment, this took over 21 minutes, it then took another 15 minutes or so to speak to a receptionist who could hear me this time, she was very helpful in making an appointment and also then getting me the email address to use for a complaint.
Two points here, firstly if there are no appointments left that day either offer the facility to book the next day or have the option to have a message saying ‘sorry no further appointments available today’ secondly invest in a better system or more people to deal with the large number of phone calls which result in the delays and cause frustration of patients trying to get through! This website has similar complaints about this appointment issue. The other practice in Goole had much better reviews!

title: Warrior team at Cedar Brook !
body:
Fantastic GP who cares and follows up with patients. Wonderful care.
Thankyou to all the team, reception, nurses and all GP s who work tirelessly. Medical warriors at Cedar Brook!

title: Brilliant care
body: I was admitted to cpau. The care I was given was brilliant. All friendly staff.the after care staff after my angiogram was excellent. All kind caring staff.

readBy.name: South Tyneside and Sunderland NHS Foundation Trust
